description.text:
Print a spindle, spin some yarn! If you haven't spun before, there are plenty of YouTube videos - that's how I learned.

This design is for the two removable arms of the Turkish spindle, and the hole in the center can be made to fit a variety of objects. The SCAD file has been updated and should now work better with Customizer.

Included are:

  • STL file to fit a 5mm diameter round chopstick
  • STL file to fit a generic hexagonal wood pencil
  • SCAD file that can be edited to accommodate other shapes

description.text:
Updated 4/23/16 Now includes guides for BT-60, BT-70, BT-80 and 3" body tubes.

With the increased access to 3D printers and more student participatings in Team America Rocket Challenge (http://rocketcontest.org/), some 3D printed parts are showing up and more teams are looking for printed parts to use.

I've created an STL file for rail guides to fit 1010 launch rails that will be available at the TARC Nationals. The attached model is sized to match a BT-80 tube size. You should be able to contour sand them to fit BT-70.

Testing of the rail guides shows that with a properly mounted PLA print, you will destroy the body tube before the guide fails.

Take the usual procedures for gluing plastic to paper. Use coarse sandpaper to contour sand the glue surface and remove surface residue. Be sure to lightly sand the body tube to remove the glassine layer (or the epoxy will just pop off). You can use a map pin to make a series of small holes (glue rivets) in the body tube to insure the epoxy has greater attachment. Stick a straight edge in the gap to align the guides.

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.200

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I print them vertically to get the best profile, 12 at a time.
I designed these using published dimension for rail buttons in Onshape. Made a sketch using the published dimension and then extruded to length.

comments.text: Updated 4/23/16 Now includes guides for BT-60, BT-70, BT-80 and 3" body tubes.

So, here it is. about 3 months of work. Still doing some fine tuning and probably forgot to upload some files so don't hesitate to drop me a line. Main feature is the box-frame design, which doubles as chamber. You can easily make fully closed chamber. Holes for filament and X bars are actually small enough to prevent noticeable convection. Temperature is easily raised 30-40C above ambient by the heated bed alone. instructions are in Polish, but I reckon it's pretty self explanatory form pictures. Motivate me to translate more quickly by declaring in comments you wish to build one. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yDGqGYUbC9g

title: Hexagonal Microphone Flag, 50mm square sides, 36mm Hole

description.text:
Needed a blue microphone flag for an upcoming conference, so I designed one. It features 5 sides which are 50mm square each, and a 36mm hole for the mic to fit through. Just add some foam, and logo stickers and call it done!   
Designed to be printed without support material, and will fit the Popular Nady 151 Wireless Mic with no issues. Any other 35mm mic or smaller will work as well. Just cut the hole in your inner foam to keep it snug.   
Will fit a 1.75"x1.75" logo sticker great, and a 2"x2" will work fine as well with a little overlap.   
EDIT: I added a bottom to print. This helps hold the foam in and tidies things up a bit. Just use acetone or Testors Red model glue to permanently seal the pieces together.

Print with a .35mm layer height, 3 solid layers, and 4 premiters.
I kept all my speeds around 100mm/sec on a Lulzbot AO-100. When printed. fill inside with a piece of 2" thick black cushion foam with a center hole cut out roughly 2/3rds the diameter of your microphone. Use 1.75" logo stickers to add your logo to each of the six sides.

title: Lulzbot Mini Round Spool Support Bushing

description.text:
The standard spool arm on the Lulzbot Mini has a square top, which doesn't mesh well with the round interior of a filament spool. Especially with full/heavy spools, the square corners supporting the round spool hub can cause uneven tension and jerking.

This spool bushing is 50mm in diameter, which works well with most standard spools that have 52-57mm ID hubs. Simply insert the bushing into the spool, and then slip it onto the Lulzbot Mini's spool arm. It provides a long, curved surface and therefore even tension, with no modifications to the standard spool arm. Easily removed for small diameter spools (like the Taulman spools, for example).

Sketchup design file included.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25mm layer, .5mm nozzle

Infill:

40%

Notes:

This is intended to be a "friction fit", and your printer calibration (particularly extrusion steps) may affect the fit of the support channel on your spool arm.

I recommend doing a test print, perhaps the first ~10mm, to test the fit of the support channel on your spool arm. If too loose or too tight, change your extrusion multiplier accordingly before launching the full print.

Sandwich the filament between bearings and show the thickness.
Works Good Enough, there is some slop with how the gauge bearing is held in place, but it works. When the filament is pulling on it, it forces the setup into the same orientation, so its more consistent than you would think. Also the extra tension caused by the bearings makes the spool wind up nice and tight.

Drill a hole wherever needed for the hole to mount the thickness gauge.

I found that really securing the tube so the tube doesn't move when the filawinder turns on/off, really helps consistency. (thus the white piece.)

Original files included. I had to play with the 5 mm post diameters quite a bit to get them to fit. The one in the gauge holder had to be made significantly smaller than the bearing holder that is held by the gauge. Probably due to my printer and you will need to modify for yours.

Thickness gauge
http://www.amazon.com/gp/offer-listing/B008H1DL3M?ie=UTF8&condition=new&seller=AA3DL1YN5S7YK

You also need 2 - 5mm ID X 16mm OD X 5 mm wide bearings. (Forget the specific bearing number i ordered.)

Also need some 3mm hardware.

Video in operation
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QY3piKnrT8c

Update:
Added a Bearing on Gauge STL with a smaller, 4.25 mm bore. Plan is to print this and then get a 4.5 mm drill bit for a tighter fit on the measuring post.

comments.text: I haven't made one of yours, so I don't have one to review.  Just an opinion, it generally looks like an ok design.  If I were to make improvements to it, I would do two things.  First, I would remove the big thick "X" from inside, and if something is still required to add strength, replace it with thinner ribs.  Second, I would separate the hook, so that it snaps or glues into place for assembly after printing, because then you could print the hole cover easily facing up (like a dish), and the hook laying down on its side (which will make it both faster to print, and stronger because the seams between layers are usually the weakest areas of 3D printed parts).

comments.author: guido666

comments.text: There are lots of ways to make snap in components.  In this case, I would suggest that you make a square (or otherwise keyed) hole in the main cap portion.  Then, on the end of the hook, add a small hook (e.g. 0.040"?) to two opposing sides.  Maybe also cut a slot in the middle.  This would create a "fork", allowing the hooks to push together as they snap in, and then spring back out into place.

title: Odile The Silver Swan - Negative Mold for Metal in ABS Casting

description.text:
This is a negative mold based on loubie's original positive Odile The Swan model. I printed this out in ABS plastic, poured in Rose's Metal, a Bismuth/Tin/Lead alloy that melts at ~208 degrees F, let the metal cool and then soaked the mold off in pure Acetone. I let it sit immersed in Acetone for ~24 hours then scrubbed away as much goop as possible and then resoaked for a further 12 hours to get this result. You might try printing in HIPS plastic and dissolving the mold in d-limonene, as it appears that will dissolve HIPS plastic completely, rather than just turn it to a goopy mess like Acetone does to ABS.

You will want to use 4-5 perimeters when printing, to ensure the metal can't penetrate the mold walls. I also print the ABS really hot ~260 degrees to get real good adhesion between the layers. Any cracking between layers is a path for the metal to flow into.

description.text:
My old frames (Bronx E Black 145) broke on me, so I designed some new ones for me to wear. They print great in PLA with supports (no warping or sticking issues), haven't printed them in ABS yet but I plan to soon.

I emailed the people who made my glasses for me (America's Best) and they said they couldn't give me the lens template or number, so sadly I can't publish what lens template to ask for if you want to get lenses to match. What you can probably do however, is print out a set and say you want your new lenses fitted to them, or order the lenses for the same model I got (Bronx E Black)

For adjusting the frames, just run them under really hot water for a minute, then bend them how you need. I tried this trick and it works well for me. I have no real solution to popping the lenses in, other than to do so keeping in mind not to scratch the coating off.

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

Print the main frame piece facing down, lay the sides down flat for printing. The main frame piece will need cleaning because the supports for it are messy, so if you have soluble supports, they would be in order for this print.

description.text: A 6 piece puzzle that comes from the dissection of a cube. The problem is to return the pieces to the box after the box is emptied. It looks difficult as the longest sides of the pieces correspond to the longest diagonal of the cube - also there are two types of pieces - mirror images. However it is not difficult and sorting the pieces into pairs speeds the solution. There is a nice illustration of the dissection on youtube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ffnVCEAcOns OpenSCAD code is included.

description.text:
Mexico City's first skyscraper, the Torre Latinoamericana!

MiniWorld celebrates Mexico City with this free model. With 188 m or 597 ft; 44 stories finished in 1956, it was the first skyscraper to be succesfully built on a highly-seismic location. It's name comes from the Seguros Latinoamericana insurance company, headquartered in the building. It was designed by architect Augusto H. Álvarez. This historical and modernist building is a symbol of Mexico City and has become a landmark. Have you seen the city from it's lookout?

MiniWorld is the collection of 3D printable models of landmarks of the world. All our models are made from scratch by hand and brain, please give credit, it's all about spreading culture!

This model is support-free and very easy to print. Use a sewing pin as antena!

description.text:
Outside Diameter: 30mm X 30mm
Inside Diameter Opening: 12mm X 17mm
Height: 155mm

I created this as an Automatic Driveway Gate End Stop. It slides over the driveway gate chain, it prevents the gate's end brackets from getting pulled into the Automatic Driveway Gear Box Gears if the magnetic switches fail during opening or closing of the gate.

I printed it with 15% infill and it is quite strong. There should be no issues with it getting crushed.

(The images are of 2 pieces, I ran out of black on a spool of Hatchbox, so I just printed a second piece to make up for the length I needed. I can't remember the length of each of the 2 pieces for reference.)

description.text:
I always wanted a helping hand, even though some are really ship, I never bought one. Then I stumbled on dougc314 thing. But I hadn't any aligator clips, well I decided that this time I would get my extra helping hand!!

comments.text:
If you've printed this out and updated your firmware, you probably found that your screen is now UPSIDE DOWN! Easy fix.
Go to your Rasbian prompt and type > sudo nano /boot/config.txt
You will see the text file.
Hit enter twice while the prompt is at the top to make room for a new line.
Move your cursor to the top and type LCD_ROTATE=2
Then type and it will ask if you want to save before quitting.
Hit Y
Then hit ENTER
You should be back to the Raspian prompt
Type sudo reboot
Your screen should be the right way up again
comments.author: tjnamtiw

comments.text: Thanks for posting that info. Sorry I should have mentioned that.

description.text:
I tried Jag's flyswatter but kept breaking them. Maybe the plastic I used is too brittle. Maybe I'm a troll. Anyway...  
I added fixed reinforcements to a 95x95mm version. Unfortunately these are not parametric so if you change the grid parameters you will have to adjust them manually (or parametrize them :)). Of course with these it's not flexible at all but anyway with 1.25mm of the PLA I use it wasn't much flexible before that either.  
Now it's pretty strong and I can smash these stupid flying things with all the required forces.  
2013-08-28 UPDATE: updated scad. parametric reinforcements !

comments.text: The perfect material for fly swatters is nylon weed wacker cord.

title: Magnetic Stir Plate - PC Fan & PWM Speed Controller

description.text:
This is a DIY Magnetic Stir Plate. I personally will use this for making yeast starters for home brewing beer. Others use them to make E Liquid for ecigs. The magnetic puck on the pc fan spins a magnetic stir bar which can be placed in any flat bottomed container. The stir bar spins, creating a vortex which mixes liquids extremely well.

Note: Be sure to orient the files correctly. I just exported them straight out of the SKP in the orientation they were in.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZQPAgM_KiDU

I used an 80mm fan, pwm speed controller, and some little .7" x .11" neo magnets.

Note: This is a rather large print... The top piece took me 7.5 hours, main body took 12.5 hours, the front and rear plates took 1 hour each, and the magnet puck takes about 15 minutes.

I printed with 3 perims, .25 layer height (.3 first layer), 40% infill, 35 mm/s perims, 40/mm/s infill, on a DIY i3 with e3dv6.

Fan: http://amzn.to/2lh3rBo

Controller: http://www.ebay.com/itm/141645156384

Power Supply: http://amzn.to/2lh3hdc

Power Supply Jack: http://www.ebay.com/itm/271757190320

Magnets: http://www.homedepot.com/p/MASTER-MAGNETICS-0-7-in-Neodymium-Rare-Earth-Magnet-Discs-3-per-Pack-07047HD/202526369

Stir Bar Kit: http://amzn.to/2lh4gdw

I used M3 x 40mm socket cap machine screws, nuts, and washer for the fan, and M3 x 22 socket cap machine screws and washers to mount the front and rear plates.

I personally used binding posts in the rear plate to connect some little banana plug leads to my bench top PSU. Feel free to request any kind of changes to the rear plate for various power options, or the front plate for different types of controllers and displays.

CHANGELOG:
3/12/2016 - The stir plate is complete and I have tested to make sure the fan works, etc... but I have not tested it out with a erlenmeyer flask, stir bar, and liquids yet. My flask should arrive late next week, and I will upload video of the test when complete.

3/17/2016 - I got my 5L flask in today and tested the stir plate. The magnets I was using were too small, at least for my biggest stir bar. It kept throwing the bar to the outside. I ran to home depot and bought some .7" DIA x .11" thick rare earth super magnets and remixed my magnet puck. I still had issues with the biggest stir bar, but then I tried the second largest stir bar and it worked extremely well. I got a decent vortext at 25% on the PWM controller, and it just got better all the way up to 100%. I also added some little rubber feet to the bottom of the stir plate for vibration dampening. I would also like to note that I didnt even glue the magnet puck to the fan. The magnets are strong enough to stick to the fan magnetically.

7/23/2016 - I remixed the rear plate to fit a 5mm 12v jack. See parts list above.

8/2/2016 - I modified the top plate by adding a .25mm support layer for the socket cap screw head recess holes so that they print cleaner. Take a hobby knife and cut them out.

8/29/2016 - I modified the front and rear plates to making them .25mm short on top and bottom.

Thread on HomebrewTalk.com: http://www.homebrewtalk.com/showthread.php?t=575715

title: EMAX 250 FPV Camera Mount Tilt for EACHINE 700TVL

description.text:
This mount tilts the FPV camera (EACHINE 700 tvl) up by 20 degrees. This is a must have when you start flying faster and your quadcopter stays tilted forward practically all the time. You will see a significant improvement in your flying control and speed.

Although it was first created using a Form1, the part shown in the pictures was printed using a resolution of only 200 microns, so I don't see why it can't be made using many other printer types. Please let me know if you try it.

Printer Brand:

Formlabs

Printer:

Form 1

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

200 microns

If using a UV curable resin (e.g., Form1 printers)

If using a UV curable resin (e.g., Form1 printers), it is highly recommended that you paint the part to protect it from direct sunlight. Otherwise the part may become brittle and break.

Tilted Camera Mount

Tilting the camera up is a well known practice that will help you fly fast without always looking to the ground below. This is a must have, and I finally got around designing and printing it. My only regret is not having done this sooner - it works much better than I expected!

Taken from: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Icosahedron#Cartesian_coordinates If you want a solid (read "working") one, try: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:65709 If you want a mathematical model of the icosahedron, download away.

title: Lulzbot Mini filament spool bushing w/ flange, 38mm spools

description.text:
I had noticed the jerky behavior in unspooling filament during prints on my Lulzbot Mini, so I was glad when I came across the thing this is based on. However, the inner diameter of the filament spools I used was smaller. I created this design to use it on these spools (inner diameter ~38mm)

Printed without supports in ABS. Tested on the factory spool arm and ~38mm interior diameter spools.

UPDATE, 24-Mar-2016 : Added version with a flange. The idea is to prevent vibrations from causing bushing to shift and spool to slip off of one end.

  • Source on GitHub

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Resolution:

0.20

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Should print as-is with bridging, though feel free to turn on supports.
Printed in ABS on my Replicator 2X. Fits great on the LulzBot Mini.

Installing on printer

Should just overlay onto the factory filament spool holder arm inside the spool.

Reference design

I imported the .STL from the other design (there was only an .STL available) into OpenSCAD, and used it as a rough guide.

author: wankahfei

description.text:
Created as a prize for Faculty of Mathematics students competition. That's why I made math symbols. You can choose any symbol you like. I included the OpenSCAD file so you can create your own cutter. Please not that rendering can take a lot of time (up to 30minutes, depends on the symbol complexity).
You might want to scale up the cutters to avoid problems with cutting but I prefer small cookies.

It is important to have good cookie doug. Here is the receipe worked for me:
250g flour
125g butter (cold, right from the fridge)
Mix to crumbs.
Add 125g sugar powder.
Add 1 packet of vanillin (you can add cinnamon, nutmeg etc)
Mix it.
Add 1 egg.
Make dough Individually wrap all dough in plastic and refrigerate 1 hour.
Roll out dough on floured surface 5mm thick (1/5 inch). Cut the cookies. Remove dough from the outside of the symbols.
Preheat oven to 180C (355F). Bake 5 minutes. Cool completely.

RepRap

Use two small screws (spare ones from an old servo mount are perfect) to connect the two pieces.

Thanks for looking!

author: Droopas

description.text:
Overview: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8s7HgMFrdTg

UPDATE:

REV A1: Enlarged the hole for the set screw in case the motor shaft is not keyed (D shaped).

REV A: I've ran into some issues with the design when it comes to flexible filament, and fixed them. The flex filament still has some path to get around the drive gear, because the piece of PTFE tube could be pushed up. The tubes also likes to be pulled down. The solution was to shape a channel for the filament in printed plastic, and add a bolster that filled the space between the top curve of the drive gear's tooth channel. Now the flexible filament will just slip, like any filament should, instead of jamming the gear.

Also added 3mm versions of parts that needed modification

I finally have an extruder I'm happy with. Easy access, and 70mm/s retract speeds. Oh, and I can print 1.75mm Ninjaflex. :)

You are going to need the following things:

4 - M3 22mm hex head screws
1 - M3 hex nut
1 - M4 14mm hex head screw
1 - M4 hex nut
1 - MK8 Drive Gear
1 - 625-2RS ball bearing

You'll also need a BSP bowden coupling (1/8) and about 40mm of bowden tubing

Insert the bowden tubing in all the way and shape it with a razor blade using the printed body as a guide. Then pop in the screws and attach the whole thing to the motor. Line up the key on the motor with the slit, slip on and align the MK8 drive gear and tighten it

Printer:

VORON

No

No

author: VELTA-3D

description.text: This thing allows you to mount a 3.5" drive + a raspberry pi in a 5.25" bay.  The intention is to use an external cdrom enclosure, which comes with both 5 volt power and an USB-to-SATA converter.

Print the plated parts, file and fix the edges to that everything fits together smoothly. You will need:
  • 4 standard case/drive screws
  • 4 for holding everything inside the bay (same screws as above will work, also the smaller cdrom screws, but screws made for plastic is probably better)
  • 2 screws for holding the raspberry pi, the small cdrom screws may work, but are a tight fit, smaller screws would be better. If you don't have anything, you can scavenge something from a cheap plastic toy. :)
    • Drill all the screw holes to fit the screws you have and start assembling. To power the raspberry pi, you can either dismantle an micro-usb cable and hook it up to the 5 volts in the enclosure, or if you're lucky, and your enclosure has molex connectors, you can re-wire an old molex-to-molex+floppy cable to do the job, which is what I did. Finally, you'll need an usb connection from the raspberry pi to the usb-to-sata converter. You can either use an external cable, or just solder some wires. USB is fairly forgiving with short cables. Beware that the USB-to-SATA converter that comes with most/some/all cdrom enclosures do not support drives large than 2Tb.

comments.text:
The enclosure I used is an earlier version of this one I think: https://amzn.com/B0093HKFYW
Unfortunately RPI puts the HDMI output on in an inconvenient location, which makes it hard to have both HDMI and USB ports externally accessible, so you'll either need to add some extension coords or cut a hole in the side of the enclosure.

title: Dragonslayers (variant: settler of catan)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The roules you find here:
https://kelvsyc.wordpress.com/catan-scenario-and-variant-guide/

To play this variant you need:

  • 1 x volcano landscape. If you already created the scenario "the colonies" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1395407) or the variants "Volcanos on Catan & Volcania" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1410239) you already have the volcano needed for this variant.
  • 1 x direction dice (compare roule-changes below)
  • 1 x dragon
  • catan chits (you find them in the seafarers expansion:http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1393862)

INTERLOCKING PARTS (NO MAGNETS NEEDED):
If you don't want to use magnets, I have made some interlocking parts for the landscapes here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2035221

Roule-Changes:

  • To determine in which direction the dragon is going to move, roll the direction-dice. The two numbers rolled on the dice match with one side of the volcano-hex and the numbers on it. For example if you roll the number 65 you find the numbers 6 and 5 on the volcano hex. So the dragon is going to move in the direction of that side. You can place the dice after rolling on the stolen cards.

OTHER SCENARIOS & VARIANTS: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1410173

Big Thx to the designers that made this variation possible!

Printer:

Prusa i3 (hephestos)

Resolution:

1 mm

Infill:

10-30%

title: OpenRC Truggy Chassis split into 4 pieces (UPDATED)

description.text:
My bed is exactly 150mm deep which put the chassis plate right to the edge. I could not find a split version that didn't modify other parts of the model and looked sturdy enough so I made my own. THIS MODEL HAS NOT YET BEEN PRINTED! PRINT AT YOUR OWN RISK. DO NOT BLAME ME IF YOU WASTE YOUR PLASTIC!

I'm sure you will have to file/trim the connection fingers to get them to mesh correctly as I left no space for variations. I'm sure with a little post-processing, it will glue/weld into a perfectly stable piece.

UPDATE: I reworked the fingers and they should lock flat now. The parts will still require some post-processing to fit together correctly. Let me know in the comments if there are any other issues.

NOTE: The fingers are reversed on the rear half of the plate. This should not cause any issues, but let me know if it does for some strange reason.

comments.text: I printed the first two parts. They fit together nicely after being filed down a bit. They do not interlock however, which would be a great improvement. Thanks for doing this!
comments.author: cpenick

comments.text: Fingers have been reworked to now interlock together as you requested. Enjoy!
comments.author: cpenick

comments.text: The idea was to glue or weld them together. I would not depend on a mechanical only joint on this part. Thanks for the feedback!

comments.author: bsneon98

comments.text: Based on reported failures of the voltage regulator on the microcontroller, I recommend going with a lower voltage to start with (6V instead of 12V for example).
comments.author: bsneon98

comments.text: thanks for the reply! truly amazing what you have put together. How detailed are the scans? What about smaller items that require more of a top down view?
comments.author: SuperMakeSomething

comments.text: Thanks!  The details are limited because of sensor characteristics of the IR sensor.  You can get a good idea of general contours, but smaller features will be lost due to the amount of filtering required to eliminate noise.  The resolution could be improved by using a higher-res. sensor like a LIDAR, but I have not tried it yet.  Unfortunately the current scanner/code does not support scanning from multiple orientations at this point, but that would be a cool feature to add, I think!
comments.author: bsneon98

comments.author: alamsyahsurya

comments.text: Hello.. I am very impressed with your video. I wanted to ask two things:
comments.author: alamsyahsurya

comments.text: Thanks!  Please find answers to your questions below:
comments.author: alamsyahsurya

comments.text: I would like to know how to convert analog into the distance (cm) on the IR SENSOR SHARP 10-80 cm
comments.author: SuperMakeSomething

comments.text: The output of the sensor/what the Arduino reads will be the same.  It will report a value between 1023 and 0, which corresponds to the output voltage of the sensor that is between 5 and 0 V.  In the Arduino code, I set up an equation that converts this number to a real-world distance.  I did this using the datasheet for the sensor.
comments.author: alamsyahsurya

comments.text: I looked at your source code, can you explain from this source code :
comments.author: SuperMakeSomething

comments.text: This line takes the variable senseDistance, which is reported to the Arduino as a value between 0 and 1023, and maps it to the range 0 to 5, which is the voltage output by the scanner.  I then use this voltage to calculate the real-world distance using the equation I constructed from the graph on the datasheet.
comments.author: alamsyahsurya

comments.text: I get the source code at a video on youtube but there is no explanation in the video.
comments.author: SuperMakeSomething

comments.text: This is the conversion between the reading to the real-world distance.  It says that if the reading is between 80 and 500, it is valid.  If it is valid, then it uses the equation (4800)/(volts-20)) to calculate the real-world distance.  You will need to come up with this equation for your sensor.  A good place to start is to fit a line to the plot in the datasheet of your sensor that I sent the link to previously.
comments.author: alamsyahsurya

comments.text: Thanks for the datasheet you sent ... but I am confused on the 4800 and 20, what is the point of the function equation of 4800 and  20
comments.author: SuperMakeSomething

comments.text: The equation represents a line that best fits data points collected from the scanner for reported sensor outputs between 80 and 500.  The numbers you are asking about are coefficients of this line.  The line is an equation that lets me plug in values reported by the sensor and calculate the real-world distance this output corresponds to.  Since each sensor is different, you will need to calculate your own coefficients for this using linear regression.
comments.author: alamsyahsurya

comments.author: reprapprusai3

comments.text: Sure!  Make sure that both the .txt file and surf2stl.m script are in the same directory as the processScanDistance.m script.

comments.author: NyaZilla

comments.text: Thanks!  I actually used an Arduino Pro Micro for this project.  A Mega should work this project as well, since it does not use any of the specialized capabilities of the ATMega32u4 microcontroller found on the Pro Micro board, but you would have to run jumpers to the appropriate connections on the PCB instead of plugging the Mega into the PCB directly.  The pinout between the Micro and Mega would likely be different.  Pinouts for both microcontrollers with pin labels and their capabilities (MOSI, MISO, etc.) are listed online.  When connecting your project, I would pull up images of both pinouts and connect things to the Mega using this information to match what is shown in the video.
comments.author: NyaZilla

comments.text:
Hai,
I get an error when compiling arduino with Scannercode
comments.author: Sembot

comments.text: I believe the compilation error is because you are using an Arduino Mega, not a Pro Micro like I used, so the pinout may be different. Specifically, I think that the pins that your SD card reader is connected to might not be correct for this Arduino, as SD card devices are often relying on the SPI or I2C interface. If you are not using the scanner PCB from the video and an Arduino Pro Micro, my best advice would be to double check your SD card reader's documentation and make sure that it is connected to the right pins on your Arduino Mega. This diagram will hopefully help: https://arduino-info.wikispaces.com/file/view/Mega2-900.jpg/421499040/Mega2-900.jpg
comments.author: Sembot

comments.text: You can download a trial version of MATLAB from www.mathworks.com.  Alternative/open source programs similar to MATLAB are Octave, Scilab, Freemat, and Sage.  These may work as well, but I have no experience with them.

Board Game - Subbuteo designed by Gianmichele Soloperto:

we will achieve the following components:
Bar to the goalkeeper (costuita to support and bar, input
in each other and glued) Parts 1-2
Port (consisting of base port, side mount Right Door
and the left and cross) Spare 3-4-5-6
referral support (consisting of base, support and engagement) 7-8-9 pieces
Side foul shot (consisting of base, support 1 and 2) 07.10.11 pieces
Out of print we will need a green cloth with lines drawn from the field
we're going to rest on a hard floor and a ball (maybe the classic ball
provided table football that is not very heavy)

The assembly provides for the coupling of the pieces 1 and 2 (Figure 1)
the coupling of 3-4-5-6 pieces (Figure 2)
the coupling of the 7-8-9 pieces (Figure 3)
the coupling of 07.10.11 pieces (figure 4)
finally put the goalkeeper in the bar of the door gap (Figure 5)

To top it all you can think about the release of the circular walls of the stadium
with forums, and any other realistic detail.

ITA:
andremo a realizzare i seguenti componenti:
Barra per il portiere (costuita da supporto e barra,inseriti
uno nell'altra e incollati) Pezzi 1-2
Porta (costituita da base porta,supporto laterale porta destro
e sinistro e traversa) Pezzi 3-4-5-6
Supporto rinvio (costituito da Base,supporto e aggancio) pezzi 7-8-9
Supporto fallo laterale (costituito da base,supporto 1 e 2) pezzi 7-10-11
Fuori dalla stampa avremo bisogno di un panno verde con le linee da campo disegnate
che andremo ad appoggiare su un piano rigido e una palla (va bene anche la classica palla da
calcio balilla a patto che non sia molto pesante)

Il montaggio prevede l'accoppiamento dei pezzi 1 e 2 (figura 1)
l'accoppiamento dei pezzi 3-4-5-6 (figura 2)
l'accoppiamento dei pezzi 7-8-9 (figura 3)
l'accoppiamento dei pezzi 7-10-11 (figura 4)
in ultimo inserire la barra portiere nella fessura della porta (figura 5)

Per completare il tutto si può pensare alla stampa delle mura circolari dello stadio
con le tribune,e qualsiasi altro particolare realistico.

description.text:
This is an open-source clay extruding print head that can be used on numerous 3d printers. It is a work in progress. It is based on pioneering work by Unfold http://www.thingiverse.com/unfold/about , Jonathan Keep http://www.thingiverse.com/JKeep/about , the Wasp Group http://ow.ly/Zt2tz , and more. The project was initiated by Tom Lauerman at Penn State University, School of Visual Arts https://sova.psu.edu/ and is being developed in collaboration with Engineering Students as part of the University's Learning Factory program http://www.lf.psu.edu/ . The work is supported, in part, by Penn State’s Center for Innovative Material Processing through Direct Digital Deposition (CIMP-3D, http://www.cimp-3d.org )

This is only the print head portion of the design. An entire printer system is in active development and can be found here: https://github.com/Tom-Lauerman/Bricoleur . Please follow my newer clay printer developments here: https://plus.google.com/+TomLauerman

For a complete parts list check the "Bill Of Materials" section. The print head costs about $30 USD to build (excluding printed parts).
A recent video of the system in use can be found here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JbxZZMp6b8A
An older video of the whole system can be found here: https://youtu.be/X4ksTKWRqvM . A video of the print head working can be found here: https://youtu.be/533dqBrCdgo .

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2, .3, or .4mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed in PLA just because that is what I had on hand. The parts are not subjected to any heat, so just about any materials would work.
After printing, remove support columns from extruder body. A pliers or scissors should do just fine.

All the parts needed to build this open source clay extruder
  1. Printed extruder
  2. Printed Base
  3. Nema 17 stepper motor (I purchased mine from Lulzbot: http://ow.ly/ZsSt5 , $13.95)
  4. Aluminum coupler - 5mm on both ends. (I purchased mine from Inventables: http://ow.ly/ZsSMe , $6.95)
  5. 1/2" Flat faucet washer. I purchased a pack of 10 at Home Depot for $1.69, http://ow.ly/ZsTrs (the outside dimension of this rubber washer is 3/4", the inside diameter is 1/8". It is 1/8" thick. (Why is this called a 1/2" washer?))
  6. Deck Screw 1/4" x 4". I bought mine at a local Ace Hardware for $1.60. I used a "Timber-Tite" brand - here's a pack of 50 at Amazon, http://ow.ly/ZsUqC . I'd imagine any similar screw would work, perhaps better.
  7. Cake decorating tips. This is the "nozzle" of the print head. There are numerous shapes and sizes available, all of which could work potentially. Two brands which fit this extruder are Ateco http://ow.ly/ZsV34 , and PME http://ow.ly/ZsV8V . The Ateco ones are about $1 each, the PME are about $6 each. Cake decorating Pros rave about the more expensive PME tips http://ow.ly/ZsVdR .
  8. 3/8" x 3/8" push fit male adapter. I got mine at Lowe's for $3.49. http://ow.ly/ZsXY5 . Here's he same one on Amazon http://ow.ly/ZsY08
  9. (4) M3 x 14mm Socket Cap Screws. Approx. $0.15 at any hardware store.
  10. (2) M4 x 20mm Socket Cap Screws. Approx. $0.15 at any hardware store.
  11. (2) M4 Wing Nuts. Approx. $0.75 at any hardware store.
  12. (totally optional) plastic thumb screw heads M3 & M4. These make it easy to remove screws without a wrench. I purchased these at McMaster Carr http://ow.ly/Zt07K , http://ow.ly/Zt0b9
  13. (totally optional) 4 pin JST connectors. I solder these onto my motor wires to make attaching and detaching the extruder motor really simple. I switch between plastic and clay printing frequently and am always swapping print heads. I bought these on Amazon http://ow.ly/Zt1kb

Total Cost: $29.58 (excluding printed parts)

Printed Extruder (cylinders in the middle are supports, to be removed after printing) Printed Base (for Prusa i3 printer) Nema 17 motor - I purchased mine from Lulzbot Aluminum coupler - 5mm hole on both sides. I purchased mine from Inventables.com Flat faucet washer (O.D. 3/4 1/4 Cake frosting tips. All shapes and sizes could potentially work. Ateco and PME brands fit this extruder perfectly. Watts PL-3026 Push Male Adapter, 3/8-Inch x 3/8-Inch NPT. Lowes / Home Depot / Amazon stock these M3 x 14mm socket cap screw M4 x 20mm socket cap screw M4 Wing Nut Plastic thumb screw head
These are Cura slicing settings we found to work well when printing with clay using a Prusa I3 printer. Thanks Leo!

comments.text: What material is the feeder tube made of and how thick is it? This is something I've wanted to do for a while and after seeing your extruder here, I think i might just follow through.

comments.text: The feeder tube was made of flexible vinyl tubing with a 1/2" Outside Diameter and a 3/8" Inside Diameter. Pushing clay through the hose was very difficult. Ultimately I went for a very different design which is documented here: https://plus.google.com/u/0/+TomLauerman
comments.author: erocker88

comments.text: How would you control the feeder motor? Not from the printer motherboard right? You woud have to use an independent controler..but how?
comments.author: federgarrido

comments.text: Hello Federgarrido, the feeder motor is controlled from the control board. It is synchronized via firmware with the print head and runs off of the same 12v power supply, via a larger stepper motor driver. I will document this in coming weeks, but it works very well.
comments.author: federgarrido

comments.text: so the 2 steppers (extruder & feeder) run on the same board connection? How do you syncronize both feedrates?
comments.author: lauhaus_comments

comments.text: Yes, that's correct. They are synchronized by using color mixing commands in the Repetier firmware. Basically, the controller adjusts the motor steps for both motors on the fly, keeping them synchronized despite spinning at different speeds. Their feedrates can be adjusted independently without going out of sync, crazy as that sounds. I do hope to document this properly soon.
comments.author: federgarrido

comments.text: cool! Just curious, which type of motor do you use on the feeder system?
comments.author: lauhaus_comments

comments.text: I use a Nema 23 motor with a 15:1 gearbox for the feeder motor. IT provides 7nm of torque, which seems to be a lot.
comments.author: federgarrido

comments.text: what about chocolate, the clay thing looks very cool and I think your design is brilliant compared to the people using syringes but if im printing with a paste id much rather print chocolate than clay. does anyone here think this could work.

comments.text: Chocolate would almost certainly be possible. I haven't tried it, and will be keeping my focus on clay. You should try it. I imagine you'd need to heat and melt the chocolate in addition to extruding it.

comments.author: Whitestbeach

comments.text: Good point, they are not listed in mm but using a numbering system. I had to use a digital calipers to measure the opening of the nozzles. I will put together a kind of conversion chart as a reference, unless I can find one somewhere - but thus far I haven't come across such a thing. The smallest nozzle I have used is a 00, followed by 0,1,2, etc. These are typically called "writing" tips.

In addition to being a safety hazard, the air pressure system was expensive (a good air compressor isn't cheap), noisy, and somewhat inconsistent (prone to leaks, and pressure surges). comments.author: sgraber

comments.text: Yes, I'll try and get that up this week. The delivery system is made mostly out of PVC pipe which is all fused together, so to document it I have to build a new one - which I want to do anyhow because I'd like to do dual extrusion. The delivery system I am presently using relies on an air compressor to push a plunger through a cylinder. It works OK, but I am working on a stepper driven system which w̶o̶u̶l̶d̶  will be more reliable.

A modified version of the man with the pony tail, -- I removed the pony tail, added a cap and made the jacket longer in Meshmixer, to try and make a Train guard for a 1:32 scale railway.
Supports to help print were made in Meshmixer, so it should print "without supports".

I made this for the side of my bed, it's like a bunk bed, except it only has the top part. I bring my phone and a charger cord with me up there and my phone's fallen off my bed a couple times. That is TOO dangerous. It took me too long to make this. Originally, I was going to make a case that held my phone sideways and gripped onto the bars of the bed, but then I realized that building a case that grips on top of another case would be really intricate.

So what I'm going to do is put some velcro straps through the back of the box to strap it to the bars of the loft (1/2 bunk bed). The hole on the side is for the charger jack.

I recommend printing with glow-in-the-dark filament. That may stick to the platform pretty badly, though.

The dimensions were designed for a Motorola Maxx 2.

There is a horizontal and vertical version of the box.

A rounded version of this would be better :/
